channel.title: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen
channel.description:
Hey, I'm making a bot for a game. I'm really bored, that is why I started it. I already have everything planned out, but I need a way of getting the current map, so my bot can quickly decide how to act.
This is just an example, but say I wanted to get the location of the [X], that closes a window in Windows. I have an Image object that contains the picture of the [X], then I would search the whole screen to check if that is somewhere on the screen...
Alright, thanks in advance :)

item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Thanks, that is a very good reference. So far, 300 points max with auto, 1500 by myself.

item.title: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Why thank you

I’ll see if it works. So far, the bot gets 100 points or so then loses percision. Like it gets the wrong height and then goes up too much and crashes.

EDIT:

Yeah, only gets up to like 142 and a glitch is that I never programmed it to under the wall, just above. that might turn out bad Fixing lol, ty for help

item.title: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

[quote=“1337h4x, post:10, topic:128613”][quote author=pizza pie link=topic=179248.msg1639828#msg1639828 date=1185867070]
Dont worry I got this figured out

if(!yourimg.getPixel(x, y).equals(thatimg.getPixel(x, y))

On the site nueb35 gave me, they showd you how to reference the pixel coords its like this:
pixel[x * width + y]

I dont really know how that works… but it will work :)alright, im trying it…
[/quote]well yeah,
if(yourpixel[x * width + y] != screenpixel[x * width + y])[/quote]
Yeah, ty.

And ty javacisnotrecodnized.

EDIT: fixed error

now working on finding the image on the screen.[br][size=1]Posted on: July 30, 2007, 08:53:54 PM[/size][hr]Alright, now this works ty. I am starting on the actual figuring out the next step of what to do in the game.

Read full topic
item.source: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen

item.title: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

You’d have to search the screen image for the pixels, and then compare them.
It would probably be similiar to this

for(int x = 0; x < screenWidth - picWidth; x++){ for(int y = 0; y < screenHeight - picHeight; y++){ compare: boolean match = true; for(int i = 0; i < picWidth; i++){ for(int j = 0; j < picHeight; j++){ if(picOfScreen[x + i][y + j] != picOfButton[i][j]) { match = false; break compare; } } } if(match) System.out.println("Match found: " + x + ", " + y); } }

but somewhat more efficient and without some reasoning error that I missed.

Read full topic

item.source: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen

item.title: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

once you have the images, do something like

for(int y = 0; y < img.getHeight(null); y++)
for(int x = 0; x < img.getWidth(null); x++)
if(!yourimg.getPixel(x, y).equals(thatimg.getPixel(x, y)) return; //really pseudocing out here, not entirely sure about the getPixel method also you’ll need a better means of comparing them than equals
System.out.println(“matched”);

EDIT: About that ^^^, I tested PixelGrabber and getPixel techniques in my bot, getPixel was usually faster by about 1 to 2 ms when used over the 756 * 503 pixels of the client

Read full topic

or how do I compare colors?

I’m still looking for somehting like

for(int i = 0; i < 1024; i++) {
if(curScreenPic.clicks([X]Image)) {
     System.out.println("found image at x coord " +i);
}
}

I hope you get what i mean

item.source: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen

item.title: Finding if an Image equals something on the screen
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

to get screen picture do :

Robot ROB = null; try { ROB = new Robot(); } catch(AWTExeption AWTE) { } Toolkit toolkit = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit(); Dimension screenSize = toolkit.getScreenSize(); Rectangle screenRect = new Rectangle(screenSize); BufferedImage image = ROB.createScreenCapture(screenRect); File screen = new File("screenshot.png"); ImageIO.write(image, "png", screen);

for that import :

import javax.imageio.*; import java.awt.image.*; import java.awt.*; import java.io.*;

if it helps :\

Read full topic
